Key_Investors: Yuri Milner (DST Global), Jeff Bezos, ARCH Ventures
Core_Technology: Cellular rejuvenation via partial epigenetic reprogramming (Yamanaka factors and novel combinations)
Pipeline_Compounds: Partial reprogramming biology, tissue-specific rejuvenation, chemical reprogramming, ISRIB (ISR)
Lead_Program_Stage: Translational Research / Early human safety testing (Aug 2025)
Key_Partnerships: Academic institute partnerships (4 global research institutes), internal semi-independent institute structure
Notable_Publications: Gill et al. 2022 eLife (transient reprogramming rejuvenation); Browder et al. 2022 Nature Aging (in vivo partial reprogramming in mice); Horvath advanced epigenetic clocks
Notes: World-class team includes Nobel laureates Yamanaka and Doudna; Hal Barron (ex-GSK CSO) as CEO; 4 institutes in San Diego, Bay Area, Cambridge UK, Tokyo

Core_Technology: Fundamental aging biology, drug discovery, computational biology, model organism research (naked mole-rats)
Pipeline_Compounds: ABBV-CLS-484 (PTPN2, immuno-oncology), ABBV-CLS-579 (SHP2, immuno-oncology), senescence programs, proteostasis programs
Key_Partnerships: AbbVie (50/50 drug development partnership), Broad Institute, Allen Institute for Brain Science
Notable_Publications: Ruby et al. 2018 eLife (naked mole-rat mortality); Schaum et al. 2020 Nature (Tabula Muris Senis single-cell atlas)
Notes: Alphabet subsidiary under Other Bets; pipeline skewed toward oncology rather than aging per se; criticized for secrecy and limited aging-specific therapeutic output after 10+ years

Core_Technology: Partial epigenetic reprogramming, autophagy upregulation, plasma-inspired therapeutics
Pipeline_Compounds: Reprogramming program (in vivo partial reprogramming), autophagy program (TFEB/mTORC1), plasma program (young plasma factor therapeutics)
Lead_Program_Stage: Preclinical / First human trial in Australia by end of 2025
Key_Partnerships: Academic collaborations, Bay Area longevity ecosystem
Notable_Publications: Conference presentations by CEO Joe Betts-LaCroix on reprogramming kinetics and delivery systems (2023-2024)
Notes: Three parallel platforms provide diversification; mission: add 10 healthy years to human lifespan; CEO Joe Betts-LaCroix

Key_Investors: Blake Byers (co-founder, ex-GV/Google Ventures partner), Brian Armstrong
Core_Technology: ML-guided epigenetic reprogramming, CRISPR-based epigenetic editing, T cell rejuvenation
Pipeline_Compounds: T cell rejuvenation (ex vivo epigenetic reprogramming), ML reprogramming platform, epigenetic editing tools
Key_Partnerships: Academic collaborations for single-cell genomics and immunology, Google/Alphabet ecosystem connections
Notable_Publications: Preprints on ML-guided reprogramming factor identification; data on T cell reprogramming and partial rejuvenation (2023-2024)
Notes: Co-founded by Blake Byers and Jacob Kimmel (ex-Google Brain/Calico); T cell focus provides practical entry point analogous to CAR-T manufacturing

Core_Technology: ERA (Epigenetic Reprogramming of Aging) platform via mRNA delivery of Yamanaka factors using lipid nanoparticles
Pipeline_Compounds: ERA-01/TRN-001 (skin aging/dermatology, intradermal mRNA), ERA-OA (osteoarthritis, intra-articular mRNA), systemic ERA
Lead_Program_Stage: Preclinical / IND-enabling studies for TRN-001 targeting 2026
Key_Partnerships: Stanford University (scientific founders), HanAll Biopharma ($300M partnership deal)
Notable_Publications: Sarkar et al. 2020 Nature Communications (transient non-integrative reprogramming rejuvenates human cells); preclinical skin rejuvenation data
Notes: mRNA approach avoids permanent genetic modification; leverages COVID-era mRNA/LNP technology advances; skin aging as practical first target

Core_Technology: In vivo epigenetic reprogramming via AAV-delivered OSK factors; originally a holding company with multiple aging hallmark subsidiaries (consolidated)
Pipeline_Compounds: Optic nerve/glaucoma OSK reprogramming, systemic reprogramming, Jumpstart Fertility (spun out)
Lead_Program_Stage: Preclinical / Human clinical trials expected early 2026 (eye application)
Key_Partnerships: Harvard Medical School (David Sinclair lab)
Notable_Publications: Lu et al. 2020 Nature (AAV-OSK restores vision in mice); Yang et al. 2023 Cell (ICE mouse model -- epigenetic information loss drives aging)
Notes: Founded by David Sinclair; restructured from multi-subsidiary holding company to focus on reprogramming; Sinclair conflict-of-interest scrutiny

Key_Investors: Khosla Ventures, Founders Fund, a16z (Andreessen Horowitz), Thiel Capital
Core_Technology: Dog aging drugs targeting IGF-1 axis (LOY-001) and mTOR pathway (LOY-002)
Pipeline_Compounds: LOY-001 (large breed dog lifespan extension, IGF-1 axis modulation, long-acting injectable), LOY-002 (senior dog healthspan, mTOR modulation, daily oral)
Lead_Program_Stage: Clinical (veterinary) -- FDA REE determination received for LOY-001 (2024)
Key_Partnerships: FDA Center for Veterinary Medicine, veterinary schools, Dog Aging Project
Notable_Publications: Celine Halioua op-eds and conference talks on regulatory pathway; IGF-1 / breed size / lifespan correlation data
Notes: First FDA 'reasonable expectation of effectiveness' determination for lifespan extension drug; CEO Celine Halioua; LOY-001 conditional approval potentially 2025-2026

Core_Technology: Distributed development platform / holding company acquiring and advancing early-stage aging biology programs
Pipeline_Compounds: Senescence programs (via acquired assets), proteostasis/autophagy/inflammation programs (various portfolio companies)
Key_Partnerships: Academic labs, early-stage biotech programs
Notable_Publications: James Peyer thought leadership publications on longevity biotech landscape and investment thesis
Notes: CEO James Peyer PhD; $1.79B reported valuation; platform model acquires promising aging programs and provides shared clinical development resources

Core_Technology: Genomics + biobank-driven drug discovery for aging using longitudinal human cohorts and multi-omics
Pipeline_Compounds: Azelaprag/BGE-117 (HIF-PHI, obesity/metabolic disease), BGE-105 (apelin receptor, muscle/metabolic aging)
Key_Partnerships: Akebia Therapeutics (azelaprag license)
Notable_Publications: Fortney et al. publications on aging biobank platform and multi-omics analysis; IPO S-1 filing (2024)
Notes: IPO on NASDAQ (BIOA) September 2024; azelaprag Phase 2 results disappointing vs GLP-1 agonists; CEO Kristen Fortney PhD; reassessing pipeline

Core_Technology: Precision senolytics using DARTS (Data-driven Aging Related Target Selection) platform; single-cell profiling of senescent cell subsets
Pipeline_Compounds: RLS-1 (dermatology/skin aging, specific senescent cell surface marker), fibrosis program (senescent fibroblasts in IPF/liver fibrosis)
Key_Partnerships: Academic collaborations on senescent cell heterogeneity
Notable_Publications: Demaria et al. 2014 Developmental Cell (beneficial senescent cells in wound healing); single-cell senescent cell characterization publications
Notes: Co-founded by Marco Demaria PhD; differentiates from broad senolytics by targeting pathogenic senescent cell subsets while sparing beneficial ones; ~$40M Series A

Key_Investors: Methuselah Foundation, SENS Research Foundation, longevity angel investors
Core_Technology: LNP-delivered gene therapy for senescent cell clearance (SENSOlytic: p16-driven kill switch with inducible caspase)
Pipeline_Compounds: SENSOlytic (p16-driven kill switch for senescent cell clearance), OncoSENS (hTERT-driven kill switch for cancer)
Key_Partnerships: SENS Research Foundation
Notable_Publications: Preclinical data on senescent cell clearance in aged mice with healthspan improvements (conference presentations)
Notes: Elegant dual safety mechanism: promoter specificity + chemical inducer of dimerization (CID); very limited funding restricts pace; co-founder Gary Hudson

Headquarters: New York, New York, USA (research in Netherlands)
Core_Technology: Senoblockers -- drugs that prevent cells from entering senescence rather than killing senescent cells (senolytics)
Pipeline_Compounds: DOT-01 (therapy-induced senescence prevention in cancer supportive care), DDR modulators (DNA damage response senescence prevention)
Key_Partnerships: Utrecht University (scientific founder Peter de Keizer)
Notable_Publications: Baar et al. 2017 Cell (FOXO4-DRI peptide restores tissue homeostasis -- foundational senolytic paper); preclinical senoblocker data
Notes: Unique senoblocker approach prevents cells from entering senescence; initial focus on therapy-induced senescence in cancer patients; scientific founder Peter de Keizer PhD

Core_Technology: Computational aging biology / master gene regulators of aging; AI virtual cell platform; gene regulatory network analysis
Pipeline_Compounds: SB000 (single-gene rejuvenation target, data expected June 2025), novel reprogramming approaches from computational analysis
Key_Partnerships: Cambridge academic ecosystem
Notable_Publications: Daniel Ives conference presentations on computational aging biology; SB000 target identification publications
Notes: CEO Daniel Ives; uses computational biology to identify minimum epigenetic changes needed for rejuvenation; $16M seed round October 2024

Core_Technology: Cell-centric drug discovery using single-cell multi-omics and AI/ML to modulate cell behavior at systems level
Pipeline_Compounds: Undisclosed programs (likely metabolic disease, fibrosis, oncology), aging-related cell state programs
Key_Partnerships: Flagship Pioneering (founded and incubated company)
Notable_Publications: Aviv Regev foundational single-cell genomics work (before and during Cellarity); platform presentations at conferences
Notes: Founded by Flagship Pioneering; scientific founders Aviv Regev (now Genentech) and Chad Nusbaum; aging not primary focus but cell behavior approach directly relevant

Core_Technology: Multi-pathway gene therapy targeting aging in stem cells (RJB-0402)
Pipeline_Compounds: RJB-0402 (multi-pathway gene therapy for stem cell rejuvenation)
Key_Partnerships: CIRM (California Institute for Regenerative Medicine)
Notable_Publications: CIRM grant announcement July 2024 for anti-aging stem cell therapy development
Notes: Received dedicated government funding for anti-aging stem cell gene therapy; targets multiple aging pathways simultaneously in stem cells

Key_Investors: ARCH Venture Partners, Venrock, Jeff Bezos, Fidelity, Mayo Clinic Ventures
Core_Technology: Senolytic drugs targeting BCL-xL and MDM2/p53 pathways to clear senescent cells
Pipeline_Compounds: UBX0101 (MDM2/p53, osteoarthritis -- FAILED Phase 2), UBX1325/foselutoclax (BCL-xL, diabetic macular edema/wet AMD)
Lead_Program_Stage: Phase 2 (UBX1325 -- BEHOLD trial did not meet primary endpoint 2023)
Key_Partnerships: N/A
Notable_Publications: Multiple clinical trial publications; UBX0101 Phase 2 failure data; UBX1325 BEHOLD trial data; senescence biology publications
Notes: Public company NASDAQ: UBX; two consecutive Phase 2 setbacks; co-founder Judith Campisi passed away March 2024; exploring strategic alternatives

Key_Investors: Nestle Health Science (lead investor and strategic partner)
Core_Technology: Urolithin A -- mitophagy activator that enhances clearance of damaged mitochondria via PINK1/Parkin pathway
Pipeline_Compounds: Timeline Mitopure (Urolithin A supplement, marketed), Pharmaceutical UA (sarcopenia, Phase 2/3), Pharmaceutical UA (mitochondrial myopathies, Phase 2), Pharmaceutical UA (IBD, Phase 2)
Lead_Program_Stage: Phase 2/3 (pharmaceutical UA for sarcopenia) / Marketed (consumer supplement)
Key_Partnerships: Nestle Health Science (strategic investor + R&D collaboration), EPFL (Johan Auwerx lab, academic origin)
Notable_Publications: Ryu et al. 2016 Nature Medicine (UA induces mitophagy, extends C. elegans lifespan); Andreux et al. 2019 Nature Metabolism (first-in-human RCT); Singh et al. 2022 JAMA Network Open (muscle endurance improvement)
Notes: Most clinically validated mitochondrial-targeting aging compound; multiple published RCTs; dual business model: consumer supplement (Timeline Mitopure) + pharmaceutical development

Core_Technology: Plasma proteomics / young blood factors; engineered plasma fractions depleted of pro-aging factors and enriched for rejuvenating factors
Pipeline_Compounds: GRF6019 (engineered plasma fraction, Alzheimer's), GRF6021 (modified plasma fraction, Parkinson's), AMBAR trial (therapeutic plasma exchange, Alzheimer's)
Lead_Program_Stage: Phase 2 (GRF6019 for Alzheimer's; AMBAR trial completed)
Key_Partnerships: Grifols (parent company), Stanford University (Tony Wyss-Coray lab)
Notable_Publications: Villeda et al. 2011 Nature (parabiosis); Villeda et al. 2014 Nature Medicine (young blood reverses cognitive aging); Boada et al. 2020 Alzheimers Dement (AMBAR trial); Lehallier et al. 2019 Nature Medicine (plasma proteome across lifespan)
Notes: Founded by Tony Wyss-Coray (Stanford); acquired by Grifols 2020; AMBAR trial showed 50-60% slowing of Alzheimer's decline; Grifols financial difficulties may constrain investment

Core_Technology: Epigenetic age testing (TruAge) using DNA methylation arrays; computes Horvath, Hannum, GrimAge, PhenoAge, DunedinPACE clocks
Pipeline_Compounds: TruAge COMPLETE (~$499), TruAge PACE (~$249), research services for clinical trial epigenetic endpoints, OMICmAge multi-omic aging clock
Key_Partnerships: Multiple longevity clinical trials (rapamycin, fisetin, D+Q), physician/longevity clinic networks
Notable_Publications: OMICmAge clock publications; Ryan Smith commentaries on epigenetic aging testing; growing use as clinical trial endpoint
Notes: Market leader in consumer epigenetic age testing; de facto standard for epigenetic age measurement in longevity clinical trials; CEO Ryan Smith; largest methylation database

Key_Investors: Consumer health and biotech investors; 8+ Nobel laureates on scientific advisory board
Core_Technology: NAD+ supplementation (Basis: NR + pterostilbene) and biological age testing (Index: saliva DNA methylation)
Pipeline_Compounds: Basis (NR 250mg + pterostilbene 50mg supplement, marketed), Index (saliva epigenetic age test, marketed), Signal (skin health supplement), Matter (bone health supplement)
Key_Partnerships: MIT (Leonard Guarente lab), Oxford University (epigenetic clock for Index)
Notable_Publications: Dellinger et al. 2017 npj Aging (Basis increases NAD+ by ~40% over 8 weeks); Index validation studies
Notes: Key scientific advisor Leonard Guarente PhD (MIT NAD+/sirtuin pioneer); ChromaDex lawsuit largely resolved; NR clinical evidence has been mixed; premium positioning in competitive supplement market

Core_Technology: Cheek swab (buccal epithelial) epigenetic age testing + personalized longevity recommendations
Pipeline_Compounds: TallyAge test (~$199-229, cheek swab epigenetic testing), Tally supplements (aging-targeted), subscription monitoring service
Key_Partnerships: David Sinclair (co-founder/scientific advisor)
Notable_Publications: Ying et al. 2024 (CheekAge epigenetic clock predicts mortality from buccal DNA methylation)
Notes: Co-founded by David Sinclair PhD (Harvard); non-invasive cheek swab lower barrier than blood tests; Sinclair involvement provides marketing visibility but also conflict-of-interest scrutiny

Headquarters: London, United Kingdom (research in Zagreb, Croatia)
Core_Technology: Glycan-based biological age testing via IgG glycosylation pattern analysis (mass spectrometry)
Pipeline_Compounds: GlycanAge test (~$299-399, blood glycan analysis), repeat testing for longitudinal monitoring
Key_Partnerships: University of Zagreb (Gordan Lauc lab), longevity clinics
Notable_Publications: Kristic et al. 2014 J Gerontol A (glycans as biomarker of chronological and biological ages); Lauc lab IgG glycomics publications
Notes: Scientific founder Gordan Lauc PhD; glycan-based approach complementary to epigenetic clocks; more responsive to short-term lifestyle changes; directly measures immune aging

Headquarters: Hong Kong SAR, China (offices in New York, Montreal, Abu Dhabi, Shanghai)
Core_Technology: AI-powered drug discovery platform (Pharma.AI: PandaOmics target discovery + Chemistry42 generative chemistry + InClinico clinical trial prediction)
Pipeline_Compounds: INS018_055 (TNIK inhibitor, IPF -- Phase 2), ISM3091 (USP1, BRCA-mutant cancers -- Phase 1), ISM5411 (KAT6A, oncology -- Phase 1), aging programs (preclinical)
Lead_Program_Stage: Phase 2 (INS018_055 for IPF -- first AI-discovered drug for AI-identified target in Phase 2)
Key_Partnerships: Fosun Pharma (Greater China licensing), Sanofi (AI drug discovery collaboration)
Notable_Publications: Zhavoronkov et al. 2019 Nature Biotechnology (generative AI for drug design); INS018_055 Phase 1 results; PandaOmics/Chemistry42 publications
Notes: CEO Alex Zhavoronkov PhD; INS018_055: 18 months from target ID to IND (vs typical 4-6 years); strong aging biology focus from inception; potential IPO discussions

Core_Technology: AI/deep learning-based aging clocks: BloodAge (blood biomarkers), PhotoAge (facial photos), PsychAge (questionnaire), MindAge (cognitive)
Pipeline_Compounds: AgeMeter suite (BloodAge, PhotoAge, PsychAge, MindAge), Young.AI consumer platform, FuturSelf.AI, enterprise solutions for insurance
Key_Partnerships: Endurance Longevity (parent/insurance integration), insurance companies (biological age-based underwriting)
Notable_Publications: Mamoshina et al. 2018 J Gerontol A (population-specific aging biomarkers); Galkin et al. 2020 Ageing Res Rev (biohorology and biomarkers of aging); Zhavoronkov multi-modal aging clock publications
Notes: Spun out from Insilico Medicine; CEO Alex Zhavoronkov; commercial deployment in insurance sector; multi-modal approach (blood, image, behavioral data)

Core_Technology: Physics-inspired AI models of aging and resilience; DOSI (Dynamic Organism State Indicator); GeroSense wearable-based biological age
Pipeline_Compounds: GeroSense (wearable-based biological age assessment), DOSI resilience metric, drug target identification platform
Key_Partnerships: Pfizer (research collaboration ~2020-2022 on aging biomarkers and drug targets)
Notable_Publications: Pyrkov et al. 2021 Nature Communications (loss of resilience predicts ~120-150 year human lifespan limit); Avchaciov et al. 2022 Nature Communications (unsupervised learning of aging principles)
Notes: CEO Peter Fedichev PhD (physicist); landmark finding on fundamental resilience barrier at ~120-150 years; wearable-based assessment is non-invasive and scalable; geopolitical concerns from Russian origins

Core_Technology: mTOR inhibition via everolimus (RAD001) for immune aging; originally developed as immunosuppressant/oncology drug, repositioned for aging
Pipeline_Compounds: Everolimus (mTOR inhibitor, immune aging -- Phase 2a completed), RTB101 (catalytic mTOR inhibitor via resTORbio spinout -- Phase 3 FAILED)
Lead_Program_Stage: Phase 2a completed (everolimus enhanced vaccine response in elderly) / Phase 3 failed (RTB101 via resTORbio)
Key_Partnerships: resTORbio (spinout; merged with Adicet Bio/Regeneron after RTB101 failure)
Notable_Publications: Mannick et al. 2014 Science Translational Medicine (low-dose everolimus enhanced influenza vaccine response ~20% in elderly -- paradigm-shifting); Mannick et al. 2021 Lancet Healthy Longev (RTB101 Phase 3 failure)
Notes: Landmark Mannick Phase 2a: low-dose mTOR inhibition IMPROVED (not suppressed) immune function in elderly; PI Joan Mannick; resTORbio spinout RTB101 Phase 3 failure was major setback for mTOR-aging field

Core_Technology: 50/50 drug development partnership with Calico for aging and age-related diseases; AbbVie leads clinical development and commercialization
Pipeline_Compounds: ABBV-CLS-484 (PTPN2, immuno-oncology -- Phase 1), ABBV-CLS-579 (SHP2, immuno-oncology -- Phase 1), undisclosed preclinical programs with Calico
Key_Partnerships: Calico ($1.5B joint 50/50 partnership: $500M each initially + $500M option each)
Notable_Publications: Joint pipeline publications with Calico on immuno-oncology candidates
Notes: $1.5B joint investment with Calico; Calico leads discovery while AbbVie leads clinical development and commercialization; focus on cancer and neurodegeneration rather than aging per se

Core_Technology: Senescent cell clearance
Pipeline_Compounds: Senolytic programs (consolidated into Life Biosciences platform)
Key_Partnerships: Life Biosciences (parent company)
Notable_Publications: Part of Life Biosciences subsidiary publications
Notes: Originally a subsidiary of Life Biosciences targeting senescent cell clearance; later consolidated as Life Biosciences simplified its structure to focus on epigenetic reprogramming

Core_Technology: Klotho gene therapy (AAV-delivered Klotho protein) for aging and neurodegeneration
Pipeline_Compounds: AAV-Klotho gene therapy (lifespan extension, cognitive improvement), combined Klotho + Follistatin clinical trial for healthy adults
Lead_Program_Stage: Preclinical / Early clinical (combined Klotho + Follistatin trial initiated)
Key_Partnerships: Unknown
Notable_Publications: 2025 Molecular Therapy (AAV-Klotho prolonged mouse lifespan by 19.7%); preclinical data on neuron/microglia improvement; dementia patient cognitive improvement reports
Notes: Klotho gene therapy extended mouse lifespan by 19.7%; improved physical performance; larger muscle fibers; less fibrosis; three new patents filed; combined trial with Follistatin initiated

Core_Technology: SIRT6 gene therapy using GF-1002 (centenarian-enriched SIRT6 variant with adipogenic, anti-fibrotic, and anti-tumoral properties)
Pipeline_Compounds: GF-1002 (SIRT6 centenarian gene variant -- adipogenic, anti-fibrotic, anti-tumoral)
Key_Partnerships: Bar-Ilan University (Cohen lab -- SIRT6 overexpression studies)
Notable_Publications: Cohen lab SIRT6 transgenic lifespan studies (30% lifespan increase in both sexes); GF-1002 centenarian variant characterization
Notes: GF-1002 is a SIRT6 gene variant enriched in centenarians; preclinical data shows adipogenic, anti-fibrotic, and anti-tumoral properties; SIRT6 overexpression yields 30% lifespan extension in mice

Core_Technology: Klotho gene therapy using minicircle DNA vectors (non-viral gene therapy approach)
Pipeline_Compounds: Klotho gene therapy (minicircle DNA delivery)
Lead_Program_Stage: Preclinical / Expected to reach clinical stage in 2026
Key_Partnerships: Unknown
Notable_Publications: Associated Klotho gene therapy preclinical publications
Notes: Non-viral minicircle DNA approach to Klotho gene therapy; expected to reach clinical stage in 2026; alternative to AAV-based gene therapy delivery

Core_Technology: GDF11 (Growth Differentiation Factor 11) supplementation as a rejuvenation strategy based on heterochronic parabiosis research
Pipeline_Compounds: GDF11-based therapeutics (musculoskeletal and vascular rejuvenation)
Key_Partnerships: Harvard University (Lee Rubin lab)
Notable_Publications: GDF11 attenuates age-related knee degeneration in mice; controversy: some studies show GDF11 hinders muscle regeneration; Conboy et al. parabiosis foundational work
Notes: Founded by Lee Rubin (Harvard); GDF11 remains controversial -- beneficial for vasculature/brain/bone but may hinder muscle regeneration; dose-dependent and tissue-specific effects debated
